description.text: You have to test the chest.
Once worn by Horatio Magellen Crisp, the crafty Quaker cap'm. Go ahead and mess with him, you'll find out what will happ'm. Crispmouth, that's what'll happ'm.
Such armor may save even you from inevitable doom.
Squawk! Polly want a Cheesy Omelette! Squawk! Zorkmids of Eight! Zorkmids of Eight! Squawk!
You can't think of anything to do with this... It's not alcoholic so there's no point in drinking it. Maybe add it to your cereal?

This parrot is no more. It's ceased to be. It's expired and gone to meet its maker. This is a late parrot. It's a stiff. Bereft of life. It's run down the curtain and joined the choir invisible. This is an ex-parrot.
Remarkable bird, beautiful plummage. It seems to be pining for the fjords.
This mask belongs to an eastern order of mystic knights known for their horrifically disfiguring initiation rituals.
A hand-carved wooden mask of the visage of an island spirit. Goes great with a grass skirt and a sweet rum beverage.
This hat looks well worn and smells like the sea; it has obviously been on many nautical adventures.

Great for the socially upwardly mobile swashbuckler, this tunic has all of the latest fashion trends, which can be updated in real time by your personal sla-- tailor. It is lined with rich Corinthian leather.
A fine example of the sort of garb a pirate likes in his retirement, or when courting the governor's daughter.
There's more than one way to skin a cat. The crafter of this multi-colored and disturbingly furry jacket apparently knew that all too well.
Beautiful red boots, the sort you typically see being worn a cat or a revenge-driven spaniard.
This gauntlet hums eerily... it will allow you to channel your spellpower into damaging strikes that reduce enemy spell resistance.
This gauntlet channels the life-draining powers of a vampire and will allow you to channel your spellpower into powerful strikes that drain the life force from living creatures.
It's like one of those creepy paintings where the eyes follow you no matter where you stand in the room. They make a lot of those on Cannibal Island as well.
It takes a pirate a while to get a pair of these. As with zebras, the stripes make it much harder to single out the weakest sailor of the herd.

You don't just buy pants like these, ya has ta earn them on the high seas fighting' sharks and midshipmen and what not. Well, I suppose you could buy 'em, but they'd cost an arm and a leg -- maybe half off if you're lucky. Best just keep it in yer pants to be safe.
Water-tight and well-insulated, but how on earth does anyone walk in these things?

These fantastical scaly leggings empower you with the ability to read the minds of aquatic animals. Their thoughts will now appear as text over their heads, just like ever other critter in the dungeon. Congratulations, you've officially gained the lamest of super powers.
Aloha means hello, goodbye, affection, mercy and 'would you like poi with that?'. Such a nimble language will quickly have you going in circles.
The Archbishop of Canterbury wore just such a codpiece to terrify the rest of the clergy upon his assent to his holy see. Indeed, all who saw it cackled in mortal terror.
Feeling cast adrift? This will keep your head above water.

Made from the right leather, not the wrong leather like that ones they sell on Cannibal Island. Also, it's worn on the right, which looks left when you look in a mirror. It's easy to get your left and right confused. That's why pirates use port and starboard, instead of mirrors. With a bit of tinkering, though, you could turn it around.
With a patch for each eye, it's just about dark enough to take a nap in here.
You'd be surprised how many pirates fall for one of these when some travelling salesmen gives them a line and a sinker. Comes with a brochure that explains the numerous installment options.
Some people are all thumbs. You're all hooks. One for the left hand, one for the right, and... um... let's not dwell on it.
A versatile tool for securing lines and liberating foes of their brain matter.
A pointed metal spike carried by deck hands for the separating of heavy rope lines, prying open of shipboard containers, and stabbing in the back of the Captain during a mutiny.
An axe commonly used by pirates to cut ropes, masts, rigging, and anything that stands in the way of the loot.
Perfect for stab stab bang bang-- but how to keep the blood out of the powder...
When you're buckling swashes, having a dagger to go with your cutlass is like having a wench to go with your grog.
A long, thin sword that can be sheathed inside a cane that can then be converted into a gun. This little blade does everything.
A walking stick with an internal flintlock gun. As if that's not exciting enough, you can remove the wooden sheath to convert it into a sword.
This staff burns with voodoo fire, and it is here to bring you-- FIRE! Burn everyone! Burn!
Dark voodoo magic binds the souls of slain animals to your cause. Also vegetables-- you're not sure why. You don't really know how this voodoo magic is supposed to work...
It's incredibly tricky trying to figure out how all this voodoo magic works, but I'm sure you'll figure it out if you just keep poking away at it.
Aetherial energies focused through a crystal create a high intensity beam of energy that you can swing around like a sword. Indeed you are powerful as the Emperor has foreseen.
This sword is perfect for your costume at the renaissance festival, and has great appeal.
This sword is perfect for bouts that involve a valid target area that covers the whole body.
A safe way for fencing beginners to practice their riposte attacks. A small rubber tip ensures that the skin is not punctured.
This sword is perfect for light, thrusting attacks.
A tisket, a tasket, a sword in a metal basket. Perfect for your kilt-based renaissance festival costume.
This rapier glows bright with divine power. It has a chance to smite evil with righteous fury, and thus totally gain vengeance on behalf of pearls everywhere somehow.
This rapier smolders with evil power. It will steal the souls of the living and sustain you with their blood. You wouldn't happen to be living, would you?
One shudders to imagine what imhuman thoughts created this weapon. Perhaps you would understand their dreams of chronic and sustained cruelty if you set yourself on fire...
Primarily employed by Viking pirates. That's why nobody makes fun of their silly accents.

For some reason, none of the Ulmish stopped to test the idea of a 'grapeshot gun' before making one that had a sword on it. Making it four-barreled was an ingenious leap forward for holes-in-enemies craftsmanship.
The Bolt Council's efforts to suppress production of this weapon insures that its future popularity will be a long shot. You've heard propaganda reports of it's inaccuracy and unreliability.
Wish with one hand and shoot with the other, and see which gets the enemy killed first.
This spear is adorned with bird feathers and coated with a potent venom known to induce paralysis.
Hardwood -or- what? Well, whatever it's made of, the long handle and broad striking surface makes it ideal for paddlin' water -or- bottoms.
The Romans weren't picky, they warshipped every god they ever heard of. This heavy thing may not have been purpose-built to be a weapon, but it hits hard enough to move a trireme.
Be that the glint of golden booty just o'er the horizon? Ye better investigate.

While some think anchors are only useful on a ship, the truth is they can be swung on a chain like a flail anytime, anyplace, anywhere. You could even hit somebody in the head with it on porpoise. Doing so sends a loud but somewhat confusing message about stepping stones and monkeys.
Used by sea captains to punish undisciplined crew, this weapon is feared by all but the most depraved sentient creatures.

Freshly hewn from the body of some gangrenous old sea dog who won't be needing it any longer. This thing has seen more action than most navies, albeit much of that from a dutch angle. Since you're not missing a leg, you might as well use it as a club.
This artifact statuette instills you with the sense that you can't lose the game, and your opponent's can't win.

Made by a false prophet of the fishmen, this golden fish should be smashed by any devout follower of the lutefisk god. Or preferably skol'd. Of course, if you're not so devout, it's made of pretty valuable materials.

Made by a false prophet of the fishmen, this golden fish should be smashed by any devout follower of the lutefisk god. Or preferably skol'd. Of course, if you're not so devout, it's made of pretty valuable materials.
This ferrous currency hails from a strange island where the iron price was higher than that of gold.

These coins are no longer in circulation, but they are still highly treasured because of a prolific collector's market. Unlike the zorkmid, which is an alloy composed of metals like brass, nickle, and pyrite, these coins are 100% silver and worth a handful for the raw melt value alone.
The superiorly valuable version of the silver chalice. Extra special loot for an extra special spelunker.
A fine drinking implement, but not recommended for vampires, werewolves, demons, or toddlers. Sippy cups exist for a reason.

You're not sure who would buy this thing, other than the enormously wealthy to show off how pretentiously spoiled they are. Unfortunately, looks like you can't pry the gems out of it. Someone in this dungeon probably will pay you for the privilege.
Not encrusted in the same way your gear is, unfortunately. It also seems to be a slightly cheaper metal for the slightly less tasteless aristocrat.
Dread for the skull collection, Pirate's for the looting and plundering, Axe for the fact that it's not a mace.
You'd be a Dread Captain too if they took away your swanky hat when you retired from the Navy.
You'll look really dramatic pulling pistols out of this jacket, and nobody'll be able to tell you shot yourself by accident, since it's red.

The Scepter; going back to ancient times, the man in charge has needed more than just his hand to keep his fellow man down. Once called 'the royal beating stick', it has been upgraded to a nobler, and deadlier, composition for the modern age. If you're properly dressed for the occasion, this scepter will really improve your peasants-beaten-over-time ratio.
You may not be a king, but you'll have earned this crown when you knock Dredmor's bony skull off the rest of his bony body.
Oh, who would ever want to be king? That's right; YOU do!
Jackets of this tailoring are worn by high ranking officers in her Majesty's Imperial Navy. The richly hued fabric is lined with a light armour mesh. Fashionable, yet practical.
This hat is part of the dress uniform for all comissioned officers in the Imperial Navy. Long live the Queen! Glory to the Empire!
This sword has a pearl and gold filligree laid into the handle. It's perfectly balanced. A weapon fit for a Commodore!
If you turn it upside-down, you can hear tiny raindrops.
I am the raining-(wo)man, right here in rainstorm-land.
On a rainy day, a Coatl go nicely with this headwear. As will the matching raiments and rain stick.
On a cold day, a Coatl go nicely with this headwear.
You're pretty sure that pearl necklaces are supposed to be white, at least, that's what you saw online, but black pearls are more useful, if you like breaking strings.
This ruby is too huge to use for making stuff which requires rubies. If you're any good with a hammer, this can be corrected.

Just because it's ceramic doesn't mean it isn't breakable. Haven't you broken an ancient highly valuable vase before? Fortunately, reputable businessmen are on call to take this burden off your hands.
Someone put a great deal of time and effort into making pretty metalic designs on this vase. Smashing it, while cathartic, would ruin your chances of selling it to Brax.
It contains a swirling, gelatinous goop. You could watch it for hours, if it weren't scorching to the touch. Careful! it's Fragile.
Only the finest in overly complex and intricate containers for our fine gentlemen and ladies. Don't mention the price tag.
This reminds you of that one time where a thing in a bottle spoke to you and you opened the bottle and had this zany riddle-off with an N-dimensional being for control of your mind and body.
I got a bag that jingle jangle jingles. Throwing it will cause it's contents to spill all over the floor.
A festive sack with 'naughty' emboidered on it's side in golden thread. Brax would be unable to resist a grab bag like this.
This amulet wards off bad juju.
One shot packed tight. Careful, you could put someone's eye out with that thing! Assuming you're so lucky as to shoot them in the eye.

The central design flaw of a flintlock pistol is that it is even more single-shot than a crossbow. Multiple barrels attached to a revolving ignition mechanism means you're never unarmed during a mutiny... provided no more than six sailors mutiny at any one time.

If it walks like a duck, and quacks like a duck, it's probably a pistol. Some were unhappy with the limitations of the flintlock pistol, since one shot couldn't kill all your hypothetical scurvy dogs simultaneously. This multi-barrel design has been fashioned for pirate captains to keep the crew at bay during the sharing of loot.
One of the most destructive and feared weapons in the pirate's arsenal.

The true zenith of the wandcrafter's art. The ability to create anything that you desire with the flick of a wand-- Well... not necessarily anything, that's really up to whatever the Djinn decides to give you.
This is bad juju, mon. ...No, really, I've tasted far better juju than this.
This wand is made of fire, it bids you to burn.

Your basic sphere of ferrous material. The application of ignition to an explosive charge, controlled by a shaped barrel, will in theory expel the shot with such force that it actually pierces flesh. It'll never truly replace the trusty crossbow bolt, but when trapped in a dungeon with limited resources, it's worth a shot.
The ammunition used by this bow is coated with the deadly amazonian dart frog venom.

A weaponized form of a potent neurotoxin. The concentrated, volatile fumes, will bring paralysis and death at the slightest inhalation. [Developers note: The Thaumomechanical Rebreather skill from rogue scientist will protect you from the debuff effect of this weapon, but not the mask item by itself.]
The tip of this dart is coated in a potent venom that inflicts paralysis. Not to mention frog guts. Yeah, let's not mention that.
A three-pronged hook attached to a rope, designed to latch on to any protuberance of an enemy vessel-- or face. Good for when you want to pull something towards you.
To be thrown, or to be used for making a killer hood ornament. That is the question, isn't it?
Muppet News Flash -- animal cruelty is not the least bit funny.
This tiny brazilian frog, while colorful, is lethally toxic. Try not to touch it with your bare hands. Or tongue.
You're not sure if this skull is flammable or inflammable. Either way-- hot stuff.
This potion hisses at you quietly, uttering dark words in a language beyond your comprehension.
A potent venom, known to induce paralysis.
Enjoy crispberries: the crispy-crunchy sugar cereal. You can coun't on crisp! It could use some milk...
Enjoy crispberries: the crispy-crunchy sugar cereal. You can coun't on crisp! With some milk, you can really enjoy everything the Cap'm has to offer.
This recipe was first discovered by the the great sea captain and alcoholic Henry Morgan. It's the perfect balance of sustenance and inebriation that the pirate needs to get through the working day.
If the Gargoyles hadn't salvaged these sentry emplacements from the APC wreckage, it'd be GAME OVER, man.
Triggering this plate causes a Gargoyle to rip out it's own skull, set it on fire, and throw it at you. Gargoyles are widely known for their dedication and work ethic.
